html.display_name: When are concentric cylinders parallel plates?
html.p: The Taylor series is widely used in physics to explore limiting cases of equations. To show you what this statement means, this section analyzes the circumstances under which a cylindrical capacitor can resemble a parallel plate capacitor.

Figure 1 shows two views of a cylindrical capacitor. It has a length [mathjaxinline]\ell[/mathjaxinline]; the inner radius of the outer cylinder is [mathjaxinline]b[/mathjaxinline]; and the outer radius of the inner cylinder is [mathjaxinline]a[/mathjaxinline].

center.div: Figure 1: two different views of a capacitor made of conducting concentric cylinders

html.p: Equation 1(a) is the formula for its capacitance [mathjaxinline]C_{\rm cyl}[/mathjaxinline]. It looks quite different from the formula for the capacitance [mathjaxinline]C_{\rm plt}[/mathjaxinline] of a parallel plate capacitor.

Although the formulas for their capacitances look different, a simple physical argument shows that it is possible for the cylindrical capacitor to resemble a parallel plate capacitor. Imagine that you cut a slit the length of each cylinder and unroll and flatten them without changing their separation. You will then have two plates of length [mathjaxinline]\ell[/mathjaxinline] separated by a distance [mathjaxinline]d=b-a[/mathjaxinline]. The width of the larger plate will be [mathjaxinline]2\pi b[/mathjaxinline] and the width of the smaller plate will be [mathjaxinline]2 \pi a[/mathjaxinline]. The smaller is [mathjaxinline]d[/mathjaxinline], the more nearly equal are the areas of the two unrolled cylinders, and the more closely they resemble a parallel plate capacitor.

This nice physical argument means that when [mathjaxinline]d[/mathjaxinline] is small enough the two formulas in Eq. 1 must give nearly the same result. For example, if [mathjaxinline]b = 10[/mathjaxinline] cm, [mathjaxinline]a = 9.8[/mathjaxinline] cm and [mathjaxinline]\ell = 10[/mathjaxinline] cm, Eq. 1(a) gives [mathjaxinline]C_{\rm cyl}=275.2[/mathjaxinline] pF, and Eq. 1(b) gives [mathjaxinline]C_{\rm plt}=278.0[/mathjaxinline] pF. They agree to within 1%.

Taylor series The physical argument focuses our attention on the spacing between the plates. We will use the Taylor series for [mathjaxinline]\ln (1+x)[/mathjaxinline] to see what happens to Eq. 1(a) when [mathjaxinline]d[/mathjaxinline] is small.
